div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,547] ALEXANDRIA, TUESDAY, JULY 17, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p:
Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.
London £ 14. 5/ £ 9.
Maresilles £ 9. 15/ £ 6 15/
Brindisi £ 6. 15/
-
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday until 4 June, and then every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.

The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. Combined fare to London by sea and train de luxe via Brindisi or via Maresilles £194.11.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: Orient-Royal Mail Line.
div.p: OUTWARD to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Oroya" will leave Suez about July 27
R.M.S "Ortona" will leave Suez about August 19.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Ormuz" will leave Port Said July 17
R.M.S. “Oriont" will leave Port Said July 31
Passengers returning by the Line obtain one-third rebate off the above fares if leaving England before the end of October.
Agents. Cairo:—Thos. Cook & Son. Alexandria : —R. J. Moss & Co.—For all particulars apply
Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT SAID and PORT-TEWFIK (Suez). 30-6-906

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL TWIN-SCREW STEAMERS.
div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES MAY TO OCTOBER.
Port Said to Tilbury £ 12.15.0. and Port Said to Marseilles £ 9.0.0.
Passengers returning by the Line will be granted a rebate of 33% off the full fare i.e. Liverpool to Port Said £ 11.6.8. and Marseilles to Port Said £ 8.0.0.
OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, RANGOON. Departure from Suez.
S.S. Shropshire 5,785 tons, July 19.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON. Departures from Port Said.
S.S. Warwickshire 7,966 tons, July 24.
Agents– Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS,

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: P. HENDERSON & CO’s LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave SUEZ and PORT SAID fortnightly for LONDON or LIVERPOOL direct.
(Electric Light.) SALOON (Amidships) FARE £12. (Latest improvements.)
S.S. RANGOON 6000 Tons will leave PORT SAID about July 30 for Dover.
S.S. BURMA 5600 Tons will leave PORT SAID about August 11 for Devonport.
S.S. PEGU 5800 Tons will leave PORT SAID about August 18 for Dover
Due in LONDON or LIVERPOOL 12 days thereafter.
Apply WORMS & Co., Port Said and Suez. THOS. COOK & SON, (EGYPT) LD., CAIRO ;
G. J. GRACE & CO., ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: First-class Hotel. Situated in Rosetta Avenue, the finest quarter in the Town. Two mintes from Railway Station. Close to Conservatory and the Opera House. Lift. Electric Light Throughout. Perfect Sanitary Arrangements. Magnificent Ball, Reception, Reading, and Music Rooms. Bar and Smoking Room.
FINE TERRACE ON THE AVENUE. - SPLENDID GARDEN. - OMNIBUS MEET ALL TRAINS AND STEAMERS. 28-26

Open all the year round. — Well-appointed Bar.

TOURIST AND GENERAL PASSENGER AGENTS< BANKERS
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.
Best camp equipment in the country! 10 12-904

div.p: Head Office : Athens — Capital 20,000.000 (Fully paid up). — Reserve 1,000,000.

Patras, Yolo, Syra, Calamata. The Bank undertakes all banking business in Egypt, Greece, etc. Interests on cash deposits,
3 0/0 per ann. at sight; 3 1/2 0/0 per ann. for 6 months; 4 0/0 per ann. for 12 months; 5 0/0 per ann. for 3 years and over. Savings
Bank Branch receives deposits at 3 1/2 0/0 per ann., from P.T. 80 to P.T. 20,000. 19-1-907

La National Bank of Egypt reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. Elle s’occupe de l’achat et de la vente d'effets sur l’Etranger, de l'escompte, ainsi que de toutes opérations de Banque. 31-12-904

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 20 June, 4 and 18 July, 1 and 15 Augsut, 5.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: HOTEL BRISTOL. CAIRO.
div.p: Full South, Electric Light, opposite Esbekieh Gardens, Large Verandahs, Moderate Charges,
CHAS. BAUER, Proprietor.

The Hotel is beautifully fitted up and is in the most central part of Cairo. Terms for pension fare at the rate of ten shillings a day. Special terms for officers of Army of Occupation. 24,882-31-10-5

N.B.—Special terms for Government Officers. All rooms facing the sea.

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature’s Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: The Engish Daily Newspaper, Established 1886
Editor and Manager - - R. SMELLING
ONE PLASTRE TARIFF
Tuesday, July 17, 1906.
AN EGYPTIAN AMALGAMATION

It appears that the amalgamation of the Egyptian Land and General Trait, limited, with the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company, Limited, is, the “Financial Times" says, not to be amplitude so smoothly and easily as seemed likely at the start It will be remembered that the proposal wu that the shareholders of the former Company should exchange their shay for those of the latter Company, giving six for one. The agreement was signed subject to the approval of the shareholders in general meeting^and the Directors of both Companies recommended their shareholders to give such approval It is interesting to note in the light of subsequent events that the Egyptian land and General Trust’s oironlar farther stated that a very general desire had been expressed by a large body of shareholders to carry oat the proposed amalgamation. Both Companiesoalled meetings for the 19th inly for the purpose of ratifying the agreement, and the Egyptian Delta Lard and Investment Company took the opportunity to seek for powers to raise its nominal capital from £250,000 to £500,000 and make soma minor alterations in its articles of association. This was how the matter stood until the shareholders of the Egyptian Land and General Trust received an extraordinary oironlar, in which the attention of the shareholders is called to the proposal of the Delta Company to increase its capital, and they are. told “ Your Directors have not been advised when or at what price it is contemplated to make the new issue, bat it is obvious that the apparent imminence of so large an issue of new shares mast prevent the vain of the shares bearing the proportion which existed at the date of the provisional contract to the assets of the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company, Limited, already acquired.” The Directors on aoooont of what appears to be an imaginary change in the condition say that they can no longer take the responsibility of recommending the confirmation of the agreement When we read this oironlar (says one confrère) we were at a loss to understand how the difficulty could have arisen. The statement lint the Directors au the Trust Company had no knowledge of the time when and the terms upon which the Delta Company proposed to issue the new Bare oonld suggest no less to ns than that the Boards of the two Companies had come to loggerheads over the aftermath of this negotiations and oonld no longer disease since a simple matter. Upon inquiry, however, w learn that the Delta Company knew nothing whatever of the Trust Company’s objection to the increase of capital until the Eire lar from wbiob we have quoted bad beec posted. This makes the oiroular utterly in comprehensible. It most be remembered that the agreement had been signed subject to the ratification of the shareholders on the 19th, and that the Delta Company would not obtain authority for the increase of its capital until that day, so that it would be impossible for the new shares to be issued before the shareholders of the Trust Company had become shareholders of the Delta Company. In any pro rata issue after that they would have an opportunity of subscribing their quota and rr training their proportionate interest ia the assets of the Company. If, therefore, the Trust Company’s Directors had obtained an under taking from the Delta Company that the new shares would only be issued to the shareholders in proportion to they're holding there would not have been the slightest ground for any orange in their attitude towards the amalgamation. We have little doubt that this or some other satisfactory undertaking would have been given by the Delta Company had request been made for it, as there is nothing what-, ever in the whole transaction to suggest that any unfair advantage was to be taken of the Trust Company’s shareholders. The circular of the latter Company distinctly, though in-directly, indicates that there is some ground f )r objecting to the action of the Directors of the Delta Company, but they did not attempt to get the matter cleared up. It appears, indeed, that for some inexplicable reason the Directors of the Egyptian Land and General Trust Company having made a bargain regretted it The agreement provided that the two Companies should continue to conduit their own business until completion, and that the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company should lend to the Trust Company not exceeding £57,000 to enable the latter Company to meet payments falling due on lands already purchased. It would seem probable, therefore, that this money, or some of it, has bear advanced, and that it is after being relieved of their financial embarrassments that the Directors of the Trust Company see fresh light on the subject. Had they sought to have the difficulties removed before approaching their shareholders, it would be possible to understand their change of attitude, but their failure to do so suggests that they were anxious not to be oonviooed.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: Oar best wishes to oar Dew French contemporary, the ‘‘Matin d’Bgypte,” which has just appeared at Cairo.
An interesting report on tbe quality of the water famished to the city of Cairo appears in another oolnmn of to-day's issue.
It has been decided to include the districts of Tantah (Qharbit hi and Nawa (Kalionbieb) among those infected with cattle plague.
The Ministry of War has transferred 18 cadets of the Military School to the Egyptian Army and raised them to the rank of'Molazim Toni.
The Ministry of Finance has opened a credit cf LB. 19,000 to meet the expenses ol the Special Court and the pay of the employés who were engaged in the Denishwai case.
Our Eeneh Correspondent telegraphs that the Sanaf of Blab Markaz. Dechna, on returning home yesterday evening, was reordered by a band of robbers. An enquiry into the case is going on.
A council of discipline held at the Ministry of War, Cairo, has dismissed Mohamed Off. Fuad, employé in the Army Stores Department, for stealing a snm of money belonging to the Government.

The inauguration of the Casino theatre will take place on Saturday next with a variety company. Season tickets may be had for boxes and stalls. On and after Sunday next there will be a matinée from 6 to 7 p.m.

The Ministry of the Interior has let the residence of Aly Pasha Cherif, at Sbaria Abdul Aziz, Cairo, with a view to converting it into a school for the police cadets, and making nse of it till the new Police School building at Abbacies has been finished.

Daring the week ending the 15th inst. four cases of plague were reported, all at Alexandria. From January 1 to July 15 there were 880 oases of plagae in Egypt, against 158 in 1905 and 716 in 1901, daring the corresponding periods of the two latter years.

A curious occurrence is reported by our Damanhonr Correspondent. On Saturday night a man forced his way into the yard or a resident of Tod with the object of stealing his horse. While in the sot of undoing the rope whioh wee tied to the horse’s leg the animal Ïtve the man a kick in the face, which killed im on the spot.

The special eoonoil of the Ministry of Fnblio Instruction, after examination of the decision of the cannel of discipline dismissing Cb. Arafa Aly Ghorab, Bnb-inspeotor in the Ministry, resident at Chitin el Kom, for uttering nntrntha in connection with facts relative to his fnnotions, has decided to reverse this judgment and to retrograde Afar Aly Ghorah from his class, which is from L.E. 16 to L.B. 30, and to redone him to the rank of simple teaser, while allowing him his present salary of L.B. 16 a month, corresponding to the maximum of the L E. 19 to L.B. 16 class.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions ex* pressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair plsy to all, to permit -within certain necessary limits— froe discussion.
To the Editor of the “Egyptian Gazette."

Sir,—Fending the examination promised by the "Chsmber of Commeroe Journal” for next month's issue, might I anticipate that enquiry by giving an opinion in whioh I believe 1 am supported by a general oonsensna i To explain the canse of the success of Qerman competition in Egypt and elsewhere one need only sum it np in two words : German adaptability.

Why Qerman goods are making suoh inroads every where — in 12 years, vide the "Chamber of Commeroe Journal,” they rose fromi 2.5 % to 4.4 %—is not because of their superior’ quality, nor of their oheaper prices ; bat be-canse, like the American, the Qerman manufacturer, following the advioe of his agent, goes ont of the way, often at a sacrifice, to suit and so win the foreign market Our polioy is to soit onrselve* ; to ram ont patterns and prices down the customer's throat. No doubt onr goods are better made, and there is a majority who .requite willing to pay for the British finish. WW they objeot to is the British pattern—as immutable as the laws ol the Meaes and Persians. When, however, their objeotion is mildly conveyed by the agent to the home manufacturer, what is the result 1 I will tell yon. Some years ago a British agent urged his firm to imitate a particular shape of spade. What was the reply! “We manufacture only one shape of spade ; they oan either like it or lump it.” And this is oharacteristio of the attitude of the Trade Union.
The result is, as the plain faots and figures ol the Alexandria Chamber of Commerce how, that the Qerman steps in, matches the looal article at a oheaper prioe, and takes away onr custom.

The other potent asset in the Qerman hands is oredit. Onr terms are prompt cash, oasb against doouments, or e.o.d. If the natives won't pay, we don’t cars, for we can always send onr good j ont to the Colonies.
The German obliges ; the Englishman compels. That is thé reason of Germany’s snooess. YonrB, eto., Xenos.
P.S.—I am not a Little Englander, nor do I uphold Mr. Dillon. I stiok simply to positive figure and fact ; whioh is the dnty of practioal Englishman to do. X.

div.head: GERMANY AND ISLAM.
div.p: The "Eoho de Paris” learns from its Rome correspondent that an important German ex petition is to study the caravan route in the hinterland of Tripoli.

The expedition, which will be commanded by a German iffier, has been organized oy Baron Oppenheim with the object of getting into friendly oommnoioation with the Ssnonssi and the Mussulman population, and of gaining over the Sheikhs to German influence.

According to a Dalziel’e message from Rome, a correspondent of the "Vita" says that the German Mission is already touring in the hinterland of Tripoli, and adds that Baron Oppenheim prepared the visit of the German Emperor to Tangier and was the agent of Count Tattenbaoh in Egypt.

This expedition has been talked about before, and may bave some oonneotion with another one of fifty or sixty soldiers and officers which the Sultan of Turkey has ordered to be made to Kanem, a territory North of Lake Chad. He also announced his intention of ooonpying the town of Mao in that territory, though Mao is a French possession.
The following is a translation ofClanse 3 of the rules which have been laid down for the conduct of the newspaper which is to be published shortly by the Legislative Connoil in Cairo :—

"The paper is to be entirely Egyptian ; its tank is to defend and work for the advantage of Egypt, to guide and lead the whole nation to prosperity, to publish all that will be deemed proper and useful, morally and financially, to criticize every atom that may in any way endanger the entry’s was'-being, no matter if that action be general or special, and to state the troth on both sides in order to form a public opinion based on strong principles. The paper's voice will, it is believed, reach the ears of the authorities and merit their oonfidenoo; and both the Government and the Legislative Connoil will go hand in hand to seek the welfare and advantage of the nation, considering no differences between faiths or nationalities, patting aside all personal ends, and dealing with nothing in oonneotion with purely religions affairs.’’
We hope our new contemporary will live np to these excellent sentiments.
(From our Correspondent)
Suez, Monday.

The S.S. Pathan. bound to Vladivostok, grounded early this morning in the Canal near Kilo. 153, and stopped the traffic for a few hours, until she was safe’y moored, thus leaving a clear passage to the steamers. The vessel is still ashore, and the tug Robots has been sent to how assistance, bat so far all her efforts to reflect her have been nnsnooMsfo'. 4t is expected, however, that she will come off at next high tide.

A few days ago an individual went to a large English shop in Cairo and bought articles to the value of 6 or 7 pounds. When he went to the desk to pay for his pnrohases, however he said that ha bad not saflhient money to settle for all, and asked that the paroel might (be sent to him, with an invoioe, to the Bristol "Hotel. This was done, and the messenger found the stranger in the hall. The latter took him to his room, and there proceeded leisurely to oheok the artioles with the invoice. Finally he asked as to the whereabonts of two waistooats. The me3Benger naturally knew nothing about the waistcoat», for whioh he was severely scolded, and the iniividual wrote his oomplaint on the book of the invoice and sent him back to fetoh them. The messenger returned to the shop, and after enquiries about the missing artioles, a second messenger was sent. He, however, found that the individual in question had left the hotel with a paroel under his arm, alleging that the wrong parcel bad been sent to him.

It was afterwards asoertainad that the man had gone to the Bristol Hotel and made arrangements for a room. He said that he had left his luggage at the station and gave the hall porter a written order for their delivery to him. It is needless, however, to say that the porter found no luggage at the station. The head ot the firm admitted that they had been oleverly tricked by this rascal, and oommnnioated with the police.

div.head: FRONTIER BLUE BOOK
div.p: THE DANGER OF FANATICISM
EGYPT'S REPTILE PRESS.
INCREASE OF BRITISH GARRISON.
London, July 16.

A Bine Book has been published on Th. Tnroo-Egyptian frontier dispute. A despot from Lord Cromer to Sir B. Grey, dated 31a May, referred to the danger of an advance o the Canal. A serions attack on Egypt seems not of the question, bat a possible raid might be attempted with a view to loaning an out burst of fanaticism in Egypt Snob an attempt would have been of a most desperate nature as a reverse would mean the annihilation o the attackers ; bat it Beemed undesirable t take risks, so the Navy undertook to defeat the Canal. /

Dealing with the influence of the Pan-Islamic Press, Lord Cromer doubts as to whether an; newspapers wonld rival its mendacity and mis representation of faots, bat opines that i should be left alone for the present, trusting t time and relianoe on the true fiaota oonvinoini the Egyptian pnblio of the folly of thoa preaching Pan-Islamism. Bat if the Pres seriously menaoes pnblio tranquillity, it wanly be the duty of the Government to resort h repression. Anyhow, this conolnsion may bi drawn abundantly olear, namely, that thi British garrison mast be permanently increase! at the ooat of the Egyptian treasury. (Reuter
THE GARRISON IN EGYPT.

In the House of Commons last week Mr Ashley asked the Secretary of State for Wai if there was any intention to farther redaa the British garrison in Egypt, in view of thi fanatical feeling existing in that entry ant in the North of Africa generally.
Mr. Runoimao (for Mr. Haldane) : Tbi answer is in the negative.

Telegraphing on Monday night, the Malts correspondent of the "Daily Telegraph’ says :—So far as oan be ascertained at present there does not appear to be any tonndation to) the statement made by the Alexandria oorres pondent of a London paper that troopi qoartered here have been ordered to hole themselves in readiness to prooeed to Egypt at a moment's notice.
PIGEON-SHOOTING IN EGYPT.
Mr. Haldane, in a written answer to a ques tion by Mr. Dillon, states

"Lord Cromer, in a telegram dated the Htl inst., stated that the order hitherto existing ii Egypt has been that no pigeon-sh oring wai to take plaoe without the oonaent of the Model of the village, and that sinoe the Denishwai incident the general offioer commanding it Egypt was about to issue orders forbidding thi shooting of pigeons in the future, bat I an not aware of the terms of the order, or tbs date of its issne.”
THE FASHN TRAGEDY.

Various are the vereio.s asoribed to the motives of Ahmed Qomaa, who was lately condemned by the Native Court of Minieh to the extreme penalty for the mnrder, a month ago, at Fashn, in Upper Egypt, of a Greek woman and her nieoe. The sentenoe has not yet been oarried ont, owing to the oomplete disavowal of Qomaa as to having committed the orime.

Justice has been suspended apparently owing to the foot that an enquiry is being instituted by the Hellenio Consular Conrt of Alexandria against Sotiris Cottai, who is aoonsed of complicity in the orime ; and it is probably owing to some legal adjustment being necessary between the two oonrts oonoerned that this delay has taken place, otherwise the failure of the Native Tribunal to exeonte its sentenoe would appear incomprehensible. Two motives are attributed : one of robbery, for the deoeased woman had in her dwelling the snm of one hundred and odd pounds, oolleoted in rents and from the sale of ootton seed ; the other, outrage committed on the person of her niece, though of this there is no absolute proof.

div.head: STBAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Carib Prinoe, with passenger and general oargo, sailed from London on the 15th ' inst. and is due at Alexandria on or about the ' 81st. I
The Ellerman S.S. Avon sailed last Saturday from Liverpool for Gibraltar, Malta, and . Alexandria, with a general cargo.

div.head: NILE STEAMER SERVICE
div.p: We learn from America that Ur. Osoar Ems, ot New York, has taken the management of the Express Nile Steamship Company.
The company’a new steamers will be lannohed this sommer, and are modern river craft.

The Express Nile steamer fleet will be ready next December, and we are assured that tourists will find that the new express steamers oan compare with the newe-t and finest river steamers in the world. On board the new steamers there will be found spaoious glassed 'observation room, telephone, eleotrio bells, eleotrio fans and steam beat A restaurant à la oarte will be found on the rapid steamers, which Will make the run between Luxor and Assouan (133 miles) in twelve hours. These steamers will run in connection with the train de luxe of the International Sleeping Car Company. A good number of passengzrs have already been booked for the next winter's reason.

Among the passengers already booked for the opening season are : Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Haines, of Burlington, N. J. ; Mrs. Hattie De Lesoaille and daughter, of Davenport, Iowa ; Mr. and Mrs. George E. Barstow, of Baratow, Tex. ; Rev. and Mrs. Henry Marsh Warren, of New York; Mr. and Mrs. William T. Purdy, of New York ; Rev. John T. MoAtee, of Philadelphia ; Mr. and Mrs. W.H. Warner, ot Cleveland, Ohio, and Mr. H. C. Franois, of Fnila-delphia. These passengers are lesving by Mr. Clark’s specially chartered steamer Arabio next February.

In the Chancery Division last week, before Mr. Jostioe Neville, Mr. Edwin William Streeter, a jeweller, sued the Egyptian Gold and Gem Syndicate, Limited, claiming a declaration that the defendants’ rights' under an agreement of Maroh 19, 1903, had lapsed, and that they had no right or title to a oertain concession or prospeoting lioense specified in the agreement.

Mr. Spence, in opening the case, said Mr. Streeter obtained a concession from the Egyptian Government, whioh authorised the plaintiff for a term of thirty years to take preoions stones and sell them in a particular distriot described in the oonoession. One tenth of the profits made on the work-ng of the eenoern was to be paid to the Egyptian Government.

There was to be a rental of £305. Mr. Streeter entered into an agreement with a Mr. Oxley in January, 1903, by which Mr. Oxley was to purchase the entire oonoession. Before that time Mr. Streeter applied to the Egyptian Government for a prospeoting license. The mining oonoession was merely for precious stones, and did not give the right to the gold or minerals. The prospecting lioense was for three years. The holder was not allowed to keep any preoious metals, but was allowed to see whether there was gold. It was not granted at the time of the agreement to Oxley, but it was granted in April, 1903. It was to last for three years ; the rent for ths first year was to be £1,030. and the term was to expire in April, 1906. Mr. Oxley was to promote a ■vndinate for the acnoisition of the nronartv. and plaintiff was to receive £7,003 and a number of folly paid up ahares on the exeroise of the option. The option was exercised in September, 1904 The shares had never been issued to the plaintiff, nor had he been paid money.
The hearing was adjourned.
Messrs. Reid and Barnard, of Cairo and Alexandria, have opened a branoh office in London at 9, Threadneedle-street. In this oonneotion a London contemporary remarks t

A sign of the times is the fact that several Egyptian firms of stockbrokers are about to commence business in London. Hitherto the market for Egyptian shares, except in the oase of a few specialities, has been a very limited one in this country. The faot that a number of important Cairo firms oonsider it good business to bave branch establishments over here seems to indioate that an attempt is to be made to broaden this interest. Certainly the reoent history of several Egyptian enterprises gives oolour to the idea that our Cairo friends bave kept the good things to themselves, and have given ns the benefit of ventures like the Nile Valley Company. This time it has been a oase of “spoiling the Britishers.”
( Aujourd'hui à Midi et demie )

div.head: THE NILE FLOOD.
div.p: ESTIMATE OF PROBABLE RISE.

The following Memorandum by Capt. H. G. Lyons, Director General of the Survey Department, on the meteorological conditions in Egypt anfl the 8udan, with an estimate of the probable rise of the Nile flood, has just been issued :— '

In the foreoast issued at the beginning of May it was pointed out that although heavy rains in Abyssinia and the southern Sudan had fallen in February and again in Maroh, their effect should not be confused with that of the early advanoing rains of the summer monsun.

These early and abnormal rains raised the level of the Blue Nile considerably and thus converted what would have been s very low summer supply into a fairly good one as may be seen from the reading of the Wady Haifa gauge (in metres):
Date March April May June
1— 5 —0.55 —0.95 —0.06 —0.28
6—10 —0.55 —0.29 —0.12 —0.84
11—15 —0.56 —0.25 —0.19 —0.45
16—20 —0.48 —0.20 —0.26 —0.43
21—25 —0 37 —007 —0 22 —0.43
26—30 —0.24 —0.03 —0.21 —0.60
These also show the rapid fall after the effect of these exceptional rises had passed off.

It was pointed out also in the May foreoast that the meteorological conditions during March and April over the Equatorial portion of Eastern Africa and the neighbouring portion of the Indian Ocean were markedly unfavourable to early or heavy rains in the Nile Basin.
Since then statements have appeared in the pnblio press that a high Nile flood is anticipated so that it is desirable to summarise the data which are available more fully than has usually been done.
Conditions nr Mat.—Rainfall was in excess on the coast near Zanxibar and Mombasa, but in defeot on the platean of British East Africa and on the north of Lake Viotoria.

Rain fell at a few places on the Sudan plains but in small quantities only. On the Bahr el Jebel rainfall was normal or slightly deficient.

Lake and River Levels.

Lake Viotoria was very high in oonse-qnenee of the heavy rains of March, April and May ; the Bahr el Jebel at Gondokoro increased a little ; the Sobat began to rise at Nasser on May 1st, and at Doleib Hilla a few days later, after whioh it rose steadily. The Jar (Bahr el Ghasal) showed a marked rise at the end of May.
The Blue Nile at Roseires commenced to rise in the middle of the month.
It will be seen from the above that the rains set in somewhat later than the average and were moderate in strengh.

The continnanoe of heavy rain in the equatorial region, Zanzibar, eto., was an unfavourable sign, as also were the unsteadiness of the air movement over the Arabian Sea, and theiUrge"Iw«mulation of snow in the Himalayas which the Meteorological Department of India reports. Atmospherio pressure over North East Africa was in exoess of the normal and this has hitherto been an unfavourable sign.

Conditions in June.—The rainfall during this month was above the average at Zvwbar. It was average at Wan in the Bshr el Gbszal and at Gor d ikoro on the Bahr el Jebel, thongh somewhat deficient at Wsdelai.
On the White Nile rain is never heavy in June and the amounts recorded this year vary considerably, being in exoess at Dueim and deficient at Khartoum.
On the Blue Nile the rainfall was above the average at Roseires and below it at Wad Medani, while at Qallabat and Gedaref it was about normal.

table.head: Rainfall (in mm.) FOR MONTH OF JUNE.

div.p: River Gadqbs—In this month the main interest attaches to the Blue -Nile and the Atbara; the White Nile is unimportant as it will shortly be held baok by the rising Bine Nile flood.

The rise of the Sobut continued steadily throughout the month ; the Blue Nile at Roseires oommeooed a rapid rise on the 16th, whioh bas oontintmd almost uneheoked to the present date; and affected the Khartoum gauge from the beginning ot July.

It should be remembered that the favourable conditions shown by the Roeeiret and Khartoum gauges are partly due to the abnormal rains of February and March, so that the gauge readings tend to make the rainfall of Abyssinia appear heavier than it actually was.
In June and np to July 19 the river rose at Tewfikieh 68 cm. in the AS days, which is a normal rate of rise.

The Blue Nile at Roseires is so rapidly affeoted by successive flood waves from the Abyssinian tableland which cause the water level to rise or fall by as mneh as 1 to 1.5 | metre in 94 hours, that a satiefkotory oom-j parison between snooessive years is dfffienlt.
This year the level bas risen 3.40 metres in ; the above period of 42 days whioh seems to be little if at all above the average.
At Khartoum the rise whioh began about May 28th, was unsteady during June, amounting to 1.01 metre, but beoame steady in July,
The level at Wady Haifa only began to rise markedly in July, 0.46 metre in 19 days.
It will be seen from the above table that op to the present time the rise of the river level is not above the average rise for this period, though Roseires shows reoent signs of improvement

The amonnt of snow on the Himalayas is reported to have diminished, and the wind in the Arabian Sea was of normal foroe at the end of June, so that at the present time it may be ssid that there has been an improvement and rains from being weak have increased in the Abyssinian area, though they still do not appear to be muoh above the average. In the first half of Joly conditions may be described as fair, bnt nothing as yet justifies the assumption that the flood will be unusually large. Bains have so far been weak and undecided in most plaoes, though at Roseires and at Kodok they have been somewhat above the average in June, rainfall at Zanzibar on the const of -German Bast Afrioe was still in excess, pointing to a continuation of an ascensional current, and atmospherio pressure has been consistently above the average.

Conditions at present seen^ to point to a moderate and not an exoessive rate of rise of the flcod. It is probable that tha breaks in the Joty and Augnst rains whioh often ooonr are due to local conditions on the Abyssinian table-land, and information is too scanty from this area as yet, to admit of saoh changea being accurately anticipated, but the general weakness of the monsoon onrreut this year renders them not unlikely unless the recent improvement is maintained.
El-Miralai May Bey, Assistant Financial Secretary to the Sudan Government, has retired from the servioe of the Egyptian Army.

We regret to annonnoe the death of Liaut.-Col. Germain, of the Frenoh Colonial Artillery, whioh took plara a few days ago at Paria This gallant and distinguished officer was one of the companions of Major Marchand in the famous expedition to Fashoda, whioh, whatever its political consequenoes, was one of the most remarkable feats ever performed by a military foroe under the most adverse -conditions of distarira and olimata.
Mr. Gerald Patrick Magrath has been appointed assistant direotor of stores, Coast Guard Administration, with effect from 2nd July, 1906.
Ahmed B*y Nasrat, son of Idris Bey Ragheb, who obtained the diploma of the Khédivial Law Sohool this year, bas been authorised to praotise as an advocate before the Native Tribunals.
